Top of the pyramid.

Yeah funnily enough i had to pleasure to talk to someone yesterday who thinks he knows it all about league but he isn't higher because he "has no time to play ranked" *plays 1k+ normals this season alone anyways* and let me tell you: a lot might think they KNOW how this game works out but they most likely don't and just talk after some pro or streamer. 
And you don't need to have mechanics to get to high diamond. 
It's achievable with game knowledge alone and no crazy mechanics. 
If you want master 150 lp+ yup you better get some mechanics but anything below, nah not really.

Yes, you do need mechanics, my brother knows about the game a lot, but his reaction times and movement leaves a lot to be desired. 

He knows about the game a lot, he just sucks at practically playing it.

Mechanics + knowledge is the way to rise. However only knowledge is needed in game balance.

And it isn't just bad mechanics that keep people from climbing ranks - some people just aren't good in competitive environments. They get stressed, they tilt, they tunnel vision, etc. 

It's easy to talk about the game intelligently while you aren't playing it - relaxing in your room while reading the patch notes, or whatever. It can be much harder to put all that into practice in an actual game.

However, I do believe that higher ranked players are able to learn more and gain game knowledge more quickly/easily than lower ranked players because they are more likely to play with and against players with better knowledge and understanding of the game. Many of them don't do that, though.

I wanna add to this but I think we can sum up skills required to league in a few ways:

* Gameplay Knowledge, IE knowing how everything works
* Mechanical Skill, IE reflexes, aiming, etc.
* Shotcalling/Strategy, IE knowing when/where to be (Positioning)
* Attitude, IE how tilt-proof you are
* Adaptability, IE how well you adapt to metas and best/worst case scenarios.

Each role has different requirements. Whille support is still hard in its own way, it's not as hard as say jungler.
The best players in the world (Pros) have pretty high ranking stats in all these categories. Of course, even high ranking players can fall behind in some areas. (See: Tarzaned)

Of course, in lower ranking divisions, you can still climb fairly high by just using your overwhelming skill in one category.

Your argument is, lack of knowledge causes low elo, therefore low elo implies lack of knowledge.

This is not logically sound. A -> B does not mean B -> A; there are other reasons people might be low elo besides lack of knowledge:

- lack of mechanics / slow reflexes
- tunnel vision / inability to focus on multiple things at once
- easily tilted
- bad gaming setup (unreliable wifi, playing on a trackpad, etc)
- **can't think quickly enough**

It's totally realistic that someone could look at the game and do a great analysis in an hour, and figure out what the right call to make is, but be unable to figure it out in the moment.

For example, I personally understand jungle routes. If you show me a screenshot of a game, I can give you a pretty good prediction of what path the jungler will clear and which lanes they'll gank next. However, I also have a really hard time holding multiple things in my head at once during the game, perticularly when csing. So, I might be playing Ashe, and I throw a hawkshot across the enemy jungle and get vision of all the camps and the enemy jungler's position. But in the moment, under the pressure of csing, I'm not going to be able to predict their route and know when I have to ward for them.

I'm high gold, but I have bronze friends who are the same way as me, but even worse at the in-game stuff; I can still have great theorycrafting discussions with them.

Hey Dominick Destine,

I'd like to use this opportunity to both clarify to you and others that might have seen your statement as to what the Wardens do and do not action in the vein of mentioning ranks. First and foremost we wish for the boards to be a fun, inclusive, and engaging community where others can share their thoughts, opinions, and ideas with each other about the game we all love. However, there comes a time where clashing ideals can arise both from playstyle differences and from the ranks in which people play. Someone in Silver, for instance, has vastly different opinions than someone in Diamond. That's fine, that's to be expected, and in fact some people who are in lower ranks can offer valuable insight to others in those ranks. For instance, despite the fact that Malphite is not considered a very good top laner there's definitely arguments to be made that he can be fantastic for players that are either new or lack mechanical skill for higher tier picks. 

Now, when mentioning rank there are three ways to go about that. The first is what I just did, a broad sweeping generalization that targets no one. That's obviously quite fine because not only am I not targeting anyone specifically it also is spoken in a positive fashion. Stating that silver is a lower rank is not derogatory or hurtful in any fashion because it is just objectively the second lowest rank that is currently available. 

The second is talking to someone in a respectful manner where rank is relevant. For example, if someone in Bronze is claiming that Orianna is terrible and is having trouble winning with her despite being a very good pick you can use that as an example to say something along the lines of, "Orianna is a very team and farm dependent champion and since bronze players usually are not very team focused she might not be best for someone in your rank. Instead, you should try someone like Lux if you want to play an immobile, utility focused mage as she's more independent." 

Now, for the third, and the one that we action on, is one I'll use the Orianna example for again. Instead of being respectful and objective with your statements you might instead say something like this. "Well you're in bronze and bronze players are bad and can't farm and don't coordinate so of course you think Ori is bad." While you're saying effectively the same thing this comes across as very inflammatory, insulting, and disrespectful. You've thrown all ability for thoughtful discussion out the window when you pointedly used their rank as a way to discredit their opinions and effectively tell them they suck. That violates the golden rule of our board and thus is grounds for the deletion of a comment. 

I hope that this post has been informative to you and other that may be reading this. In the future I trust you will keep this in mind for both your own personal conduct and approach to the boards as well as knowing exactly what kind of comments are considered valid reports. 

Good luck out there Summoner!
